item.title: All Bosses in The First Berserker Khazan—How Many Bosses Are There?
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/all-bosses-in-the-first-berserker-khazan-how-many-bosses-are-there/

Fighting mobs is fun, but we’re after The First Berserker Khazan’s bosses for the tense, multi-hour fights that leave you wanting to pummel your controller. We’ve rounded up every main boss fight in the game and can tell you how many there are.

The First Berserker Khazan is one of the hardest Soulslikes I’ve ever played. I’m not sure how Neople managed it, but they’ve put together a collection of unique, challenging, and rewarding boss fights. Very rarely are they unfair, either—a rarity, as when I die in a Souls game, I blame anyone but myself.

The boss fights in Khazan are fantastic. If you’re just starting or wondering how many are left, you’ve come to the right place.

How Many Bosses Are in The First Berserker Khazan?

There are 16 main bosses and a further 10 optional side bosses in The First Berserker Khazan.

If you want to beat The First Berserker Khazan, you need to overcome 16 boss fights. Encounters can have several phases, and enemies have a large moveset of attacks they inevitably cycle through.

I had the pain of fighting pre-patch Viper before it was nerfed, and I can tell you I spent over 2 hours on this fight alone! Your mileage will vary depending on your ability, your patience, and how adept you are at studying and memorizing attacks.

Also, there are ways to make particular boss fights easier. The Aratra fight—for example—requires you to target the enemy’s weak points to inflict massive damage. If you coordinate your attack well enough, you can lop off its limbs simultaneously and bring yourself very close to the finishing line.

Every Boss in The First Berserker Khazan

Here are two complete lists showing you every First Berserker Khazan boss. Spoiler warning here as you might want to keep some of these names a secret.

You have been warned.

Main Bosses

  • Yetuga
  • Blade Phantom
  • Viper
  • Volbaino
  • Aratra
  • Rangkus
  • Maluca
  • Elamein
  • Shactuka
  • Trokka
  • Bellerian
  • Skalpel
  • Princess Ilyna
  • Hismar
  • Reese
  • Ozma

Side Bosses

  • Keshta the Unyielding
  • Specter of Bhangau
  • Bearius
  • Xaldin
  • Mutated Xilence
  • Bringkus
  • Yeturak
  • Sergei
  • Yerid the Completed
  • Failed Creation

We have many more The First Berserker Khazan guides to check out. Our content shows you how to get and use Soulstones, how to get more Netherworld Energy, and who voices Khazan.

item.title: Eidos-Montreal, Another Embracer Studio, Suffers Large-Scale Layoffs
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/eidos-montreal-another-embracer-studio-suffers-large-scale-layoffs/

Eidos-Montreal, a development studio known for Marvel’s Guardians of the Galaxy and support on games like Marvel’s Avengers and Tomb Raider, has announced a wave of large-scale layoffs.

The Embracer-owned studio posted on social media on Monday afternoon that it was letting go 75 employees.

“Today, we informed our studio staff that we are going to let go up to 75 valuable members, as one of our mandates is coming to an end,” the article reads. “It is not a reflection of their dedication or skills, but unfortunately, we don’t have the capacity to entirely reallocate them to our other ongoing projects and services.

“These very talented, highly experienced experts are going to enter the employment market, and we are working to support them through this transition.”

The studio closed its statement saying that it was “committed to deliver” the projects it has currently in development.

Currently, Eidos-Montreal is supporting Playground Games on the Fable reboot that is scheduled to launch in 2026. The game’s delay into 2026 was recently announced by Playground Games.

Insider Gaming has reached out to Embracer Group about the layoffs at Eidos-Montreal and whether the Fable delay had anything to do with the decision. Should a response be received, it will be added to this article.

item.title: Riot is Reportedly Filming a Live-Action League of Legends Series in Vietnam
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/riot-is-reportedly-filming-a-live-action-league-of-legends-series-in-vietnam/

Building on the success of the Arcane series on Netflix, Riot Games is reportedly considering a live-action project for its next series. The developers of League of Legends are also reportedly close to finalizing a shoot locations that will bring one of the game’s iconic regions to life.

Will the Pirate Haven of Bilgewater Be Brought to Life in Vietnam?

According to a post from an official Vietnamese government Facebook account, Riot is planning to film a nine episode television series based on League of Legends later this year. Riot is reportedly very interested in the Cát Bà Archipelago in northern Vietnam as a filming location, and could start shooting by the end of 2025.

Among the Riot representatives that met with Vietnam’s Minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism was Rose Lam, a long-time executive producer for shows like The Last of Us and Altered Carbon. According to Lam, Riot Studios surveyed many other countries in Asia including Japan, Korea, and Thailand, but found Vietnam to be the most suitable.

Earlier today, esports and gaming news outlet Sheep Esports speculated that the “rugged cliffs, deep blue waters, and maritime atmosphere of Cát Bà” point toward a series that could be set in the region of Bilgewater. In League of Legends’ lore, Bilgewater is a port city and pirate haven, home to several nautical or sea-faring in-game champions like Gangplank, Tahm Kench, and Miss Fortune, among others. The first two seasons of Arcane took place in the glittering, progressive city of Piltover and the dark, industrial undercity of Zaun.

The success of both Arcane and other live-action video game series has evidently Riot to motivation to pursue a live-action show of its own. Arcane received massive critical acclaim, especially in its first season, leading to numerous awards in the field of animation. In the past two years, two different live action shows based on games, Fallout and The Last of Us, have been met with critical acclaim and commercial success.

item.title: Developers Say Nintendo Switch 2 Dev Kits Don’t Have 4K Output
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/developers-say-nintendo-switch-2-dev-kits-dont-have-4k-output/

The Nintendo Switch 2 is set to get its full reveal on April 2, and there are plenty of rumors and speculation about what the latest console from Nintendo will feature. One such rumor is that the Nintendo Switch 2 will support 4K resolution in some fashion.

Past rumors suggest that the Switch 2 will support 4K when docked. When in handheld, however, it will have a 1080p resolution.

Despite the claims of 4K support, however, there is some question as to whether that’s accurate based on what was said during the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco earlier this month.

“I heard this from one developer at GDC and also heard it separately in an email but the dev kits, or some of the dev kits, don’t have a 4K output,” Insider Gaming’s Tom Henderson said during the latest episode of Insider Gaming Weekly.

It should be emphasized that the lack of 4K output on a dev kit doesn’t automatically mean that the system won’t support it. Console development kits don’t often fully match the specs of the final system. For example, some dev kits could offer more memory to allow for better debugging and leave out features that don’t impact testing too much like, in this instance, a 4K output.

Sticking on the topic of dev kits, to follow up on a prior Insider Gaming report on developers expecting them in June, it was clarified that it’s likely that some of the major third-party developers have them already. It’s the smaller studios that are still waiting on them to come in.

item.title: RuneScape: Dragonwilds Announced With Spring 2025 Early Access
item.content:encoded:
https://insider-gaming.com/runescape-dragonwilds-announced-with-spring-2025-early-access/

Jagex has officially revealed its new game in the RuneScape franchise called RuneScape: Dragonwilds. The game, set in the same universe as the traditional RuneScape titles is set to release in early access this spring.

RuneScape: Dragonwilds takes place on the continent of Ashenfall where up to four players work together to build camps, improve skills, and work to survive a land where “dragons have awoken”.

“Journey through the vast, vibrant regions of Ashenfall and unveil the ruins of forgotten civilisations to discover why wild, transformative magic spills from its fractured lands,” the game’s description reads. “Explode ore veins with a snap of your fingers. Conjure a spectral axe to chop down a line of trees in an instant. The Anima-rich landscape of Ashenfall offers you a power unlike any other.”

There will also be various quests to complete while level up your skills and even wield the runes the series is known for.

The continent itself will be made up of two regions with give biomes. Players of the franchise will be able to recognize various creatures from the series, however they will look a bit different due to the magic of Ashenfall. Some will be fused with thorns or other plant elements.

Ahead of the game’s early access release later this spring, Jagex will be holding a deep-dive for players on April 15 at Noon ET/9am PT. Though not confirmed, it’s expected that an early access release date will be announced at, our around, the deep dive event.
